AN IMPORTANT PASSENGER ON THE TAURUS EXPRESS

uniform conversing with a small man muffled up to the ears of whom nothing was visible but a
pinktipped nose and the two points of an upwardcurled moustache.

It was freezingly cold and this job of seeing off a distinguished stranger was not one to be
envied but Lieutenant Dubosc performed his part manfully.

Graceful phrases fell from his lips in
polished French.
Not that he knew what it was all about.

There had been rumours of course as
there always were in such cases.

The General’s—his General’s—temper had grown worse and
worse.

A
very distinguished officer had committed suicide another had suddenly resigned anxious faces

And the General
